executive_summary: The industry produces potatoes, sweet potatoes and yams for sale to fresh markets and food processors. Potatoes are the most widely produced vegetable in the United States and form a well-accepted component of prepared dishes and snack foods, including French fries and potato chips. In fact, over 50.0% of the annual potato crop is destined to become French fries, with about 70.0% of industry revenue stemming from sales to food processors in 2021 (latest data available). Overall, potato farmers have worked to reduce production to uplift potato prices, which has had a mixed effect on industry revenue growth.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Potato farming revenue has decreased at a CAGR of 0.4% to $5.2 billion through the end of 2023, including a 1.5% increase in 2023 alone, when profit will fall to 1.1%.
Potato farming revenue has seen an overall decline in recent years as per capita fruit and vegetable consumption has fallen along with potato production.

Imports are expected to account for over 10.0% of domestic demand for industry products in 2023, with the majority of imports coming from Canada. Exports are expected to account for over 10.0% of industry revenue in 2023, with most exports going to Canada and Mexico.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Revenue will rise at a CAGR of 0.7% over the next five years to $5.3 billion through the end of 2028, when profit will stagnate at 1.1%.

The price of vegetables is set to continue to rise from its current elevated state, driving revenue growth for the potato farming industry. As the population continues to see steady growth, demand for potatoes will expand.

Potato farmers will update their product selection to accommodate new domestic markets. Presently, the majority of potatoes produced in the United States go to food processors for products such as potato chips and French fries.
As the US dollar is set to depreciate in the coming years, competition from imports is set to decline as American potatoes become more competitive globally.

industry_definition: This industry grows potatoes, sweet potatoes and yams. Potatoes are a staple food product in many parts of the world and can also be used to in the manufacture of other products, including processed snack foods, alcoholic spirits and animal feed.
key_trends: The industry is a major supplier to food processing industries
Industry participation has decreased due to volatile price conditions
The United States imports potatoes almost exclusively from Canada

market_segmentation.segment_description: This segment represents sales to the processing market, which food manufacturers and potato processors, both frozen and otherwise. Potatoes that are grown for processing are usually harvested mechanically and transported in bulk containers to processing plants; a large share of these potatoes is grown under long-term contracts.
This segment represents sales to other food processors besides frozen food processors.

This segment accounts for the sales of fresh potatoes to supermarkets, grocery stores and farmers markets. Supermarkets and other retail outlets put an emphasis on quality by moving the produce quickly from the farm to the consumer.
This segment accounts for sales of potatoes to markets other than food processors or fresh markets, including for use as feed or as seed.

products_and_services.product_description: This segment accounts for the sales of potatoes to be used fresh by the end consumer. The tuber quality of the potato plant is the factor that distinguishes the crop from being fresh or processed. For the fresh market, a potato must be consistent in shape and size, with quality skins.

This segment accounts for sales potatoes used for processing. While fresh potatoes are valued by their shape and quality of skin, processed potatoes are evaluated by other measures. For French fries, chips and other processed potato products the potatoes must have high dry matter content to achieve a good color.
This segment accounts for sales potatoes used for processing into chips. Processed potatoes are treated differently depending on which end user they are shipped to.
This segment accounts for sales of potatoes used for dehydrating as part of processing.
This segment accounts for sales of potatoes used for canning as part of processing.

This segment accounts for sales of sweet potatoes and other (including feed, seed and other processing potatoes). Sweet potatoes, while they resemble potatoes, are a different vegetable. They are orange in color and can be found in most grocery stores and supermarkets.

tier_1_suppliers: Electric Power Transmission in the US
Coal & Natural Gas Power in the US
Tractors & Agricultural Machinery Manufacturing in the US
Commercial Building Construction in the US
Water Supply & Irrigation Systems in the US
tier_1_buyers: Frozen Food Production in the US
Canned Fruit & Vegetable Processing in the US
Fruit & Vegetable Markets in the US
tier_2_buyers: Supermarkets & Grocery Stores in the US
Warehouse Clubs & Supercenters in the US
Fruit & Vegetable Wholesaling in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Population growth is a significant factor in determining demand for potatoes. Because many of these products are staples of the conventional US diet, a boost in population also increases demand for potato products.

Rising nutritional awareness and a preference for a produce-rich diet across the nation has had a positive effect on demand for foods such as potatoes. The Food and Drug Administration's recommendations for low-fat diets and increased media attention on nutrition have helped raise consumer awareness about the benefits of consuming natural foods.

Any large increase in the price of potato crops can constrain demand and encourage consumption of alternative foods. But potatoes are a staple of the US diet and are generally one of the least expensive forms of produce on the market. Therefore, a price change would need to be drastic to have a substantial negative effect on demand for industry products.

Exchange rate movements directly affect demand for US potatoes in foreign markets. Similar to domestic manufacturers, overseas customers are sensitive to price increases. Any appreciation in the value of the US dollar would likely erode the price competitiveness of domestically produced potatoes abroad.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Canada has consistently been the leading source of imports, accounting for over 70.0% of import revenue. China and Jamaica are other sources of imports, with a larger share of sweet potato imports.
Canada and Mexico are the leading destinations for exports, benefiting from proximity and trade agreements. The Netherlands and UK also exhibit demand for US potato exports.

business_locations.location_description: The Rocky Mountains region accounts for the nation's largest share of potato production, led by Idaho. It has around 35% of establishments but only 10% of the population.
The West Plains region has around 25% of establishments and 15% of the population.
The Great Lakes region has around 15% of establishments and 20% of the population.
The New England region has around 5% of establishments and 5% of the population.
The Southeast region has around 10% of establishments and 20% of the population.
The Southwest region has around 5% of establishments and 15% of the population.
The Mid-Atlantic region has around 5% of establishments and 15% of the population.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The EPA closely regulates the industry's use of farm chemicals and pesticides, requiring registration and studies.
All potato seeds must be federally inspected and meet criteria aimed at reducing disease and contamination before planting.
Growers of genetically modified potatoes must be licensed, and manufacturers must obtain renewable licenses from EPA, USDA and FDA.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The potato farming industry is mature.
The industry has a high level of capital intensity.

factors_decreased_barrier: The industry has a low level of market concentration.
The industry has a low to steady level of globalization.
The industry has a low to steady level of competition.

basis_points.basis_description: Production costs and quality are key points of competition among industry operators. Farmers that can produce potatoes at lower costs gain a competitive advantage. Potato quality factors like size and shape also differentiate potatoes.

Potato growers must compete with other produce providers and processed foods in the snack and meal segment. Rice and pasta have gained market share. Growers must deliver high quality to compete effectively.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Market share concentration is low, but large producers hold a considerably larger share than in some other agricultural industries.
Producers like RD Offutt Company, Wada Farms and Black Gold Farms are franchise-run operations, unusual for a crop production industry.
The industry has significantly consolidated growing operations according to the USDA Census of Agriculture, with the number of potato farms decreasing from 21,079 in 2012 to 16,554 in 2017.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Fertilizer is the largest purchase expense. In recent years, fertilizer prices have dropped, allowing purchases to have declined as a share of revenue.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The industry experiences a high level of capital intensity. Potato farming requires extensive capital investments in agricultural machinery and equipment.
IBISWorld estimates that for every $1.00 the industry spends on labor, an estimated $0.33 is invested in capital in 2023.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Drastic changes in weather as a result of drought or natural disaster can have serious implications for potato farmers.
Changes in government grants, subsidies and market prices of substitutable vegetables affect industry revenue.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Manufacturers have incorporated satellite technology into agricultural machinery to increase precision of crop harvesting.
Genetically modified potatoes have been developed for traits like herbicide resistance, increased starch, and ability to grow in extreme climates.

FAQs.question: Do your sales depend on the overall health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Demand for potatoes and foodstuffs tend to be stable and sales of which are more dependent on disposable income levels. Consumers will trade down for inferior products during tough economic times and trade up for higher-margin goods during favorable economic conditions.

FAQs.question: Does your company produce just one variety of vegetables or an array?
Has your company been exposed to excess revenue volatility?
FAQs.answer: Producers that enter into long-term supply contracts with downstream customers will exhibit more stable revenue. Producers that exercise input-price and supply management will have a better time planning next year's crop, boosting potential profitability.

FAQs.question: Is your company located in proximity to key buying and selling markets?
FAQs.answer: Producers located in proximity to key selling markets will exhibit lower transportation costs and higher profitability. Producers located in proximity to key input suppliers will exhibit lower purchase costs and higher profitability.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging the latest technologies?
FAQs.answer: Crop yields can be improved and stabilized via automated technology such as drones and crop monitors, making for more stable harvests. Labor costs can further be reduced through the use of seasonal labor in conjunction with the latest technologies.

FAQs.question: Has your company been able to reduce wage costs via automation?
FAQs.answer: Labor costs can be reduced by adopting auto-steering and GPS guided tractors. Operators leveraging the latest technologies will exhibit higher operating efficiency and higher profitability.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all occupational health and safety requirements are upheld?
FAQs.answer: Compliant producers will exhibit lower insurance premiums and costs, boosting profitability. Noncompliant producers will be subject to insurance cost increases, undercutting profitability.

FAQs.question: Is your company prepared to adapt to shifting environmental regulations?
FAQs.answer: Producers with a penchant for environmentally friendly and organic produce may be favored by the public. Noncompliant producers will be subject to fines and penalties, limiting profitability.

FAQs.question: Has your company had any difficulty financing current operations?
FAQs.answer: Producers that enter into long-term supply contracts will have more stable revenue, enduring price declines better and protecting against profit margin volatility. Oftentimes agricultural producers will produce at a loss, which is then made up for via government subsidies.

FAQs.question: How does your profit margin compare to those of your biggest competitors?
FAQs.answer: Producers that adopt the latest technologies will exhibit higher operating efficiencies. Producers that enter into long-term supply contracts will exhibit lower revenue volatility and higher profitability.

FAQs.question: How much of your production is devoted to premium products? Do you spend on marketing to position your products as top quality?
FAQs.answer: Farmers who produce premium potatoes can attract buyers in premium markets where prices are highest and increase profit.

FAQs.question: How do you assess biophysical conditions for a plantation? How frequently do conditions need to be assessed?
FAQs.answer: The presence of fertile soils and other appropriate growing conditions play a critical role in shaping the success of growing potatoes.

FAQs.question: Has your company developed export markets? If so, is there capacity to increase export volumes?
FAQs.answer: Operators that have the ability to identify and market potatoes to consumers overseas can reduce farmers' reliance on the domestic market.

FAQs.question: How have sales trended in recent years? Do you track the price of vegetables?
FAQs.answer: An increase in the price of vegetables, including potatoes, sweet potatoes and yams, affects returns at the farm level. When the prices of these products increase, farmers collect higher returns.

FAQs.question: Is your farm located in a region that receives an appropriate amount of rainfall? Do you track average annual precipitation?
FAQs.answer: Potatoes, sweet potatoes and yams require a particular amount of soil moisture to grow. However, excessive rainfall can damage crops and decimate yields, which often translates to low profit margins and revenue.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your yield goes to food processors? Is this a growing market for you?
FAQs.answer: More than half of industry products are delivered to food processors for the manufacture of foods such as potato chips and french fries.
